dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey, welcome back to the podcast, everyone! Today, we're diving into the complexities of global trade and international pressure tactics, and, uh, it's pretty messy out there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey, welcome back to the podcast, everyone! Today, we're diving into the complexities of global trade and international pressure tactics, and, uh, it's pretty messy out there.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, A, it really is. You'd think there are clear rules, right? Like the WTO, which has, you know, procedures for when trading partners violate rules, especially the most-favored-nation principle.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, A, it really is. You'd think there are clear rules, right? Like the W T O, which has, you know, procedures for when trading partners violate rules, especially the most-favored-nation principle.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Similarly, the World Trade Organizations articles, which underpin the international trading system, outline procedures for member countries to follow when trading partners violate the organizations rules, particularly the most-favored-nation principle.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. But then you have situations, like, former US President Trump. He slapped tariffs on steel and aluminum, citing "national security." A lot of partners, though, saw it as a fig leaf for protectionism.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. But then you have situations, like, former U S President Trump. He slapped tariffs on steel and aluminum, citing national security. A lot of partners, though, saw it as a fig leaf for protectionism.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When former US President Donald Trump, citing national-security concerns, imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, many of the United States trading partners viewed this as a fig leaf for protectionism and filed complaints with the WTO.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] And then they filed complaints with the WTO, but, uh, America's refusal to appoint new judges has basically left the dispute-settlement body non-functional. It's like, what now?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then they filed complaints with the W T O, but, uh, America's refusal to appoint new judges has basically left the dispute-settlement body non-functional. It's like, what now?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But Americas refusal to appoint new judges to the WTOs dispute-settlement body has left members without a functional mechanism to resolve such conflicts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which kinda brings us to sanctions, right? If formal dispute resolution is stalled, what other levers do countries pull?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which kinda brings us to sanctions, right? If formal dispute resolution is stalled, what other levers do countries pull?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, goods sanctions, like those against South Africa in the 80s, were super effective because they were almost universal. But, uh, otherwise, they often fail.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, goods sanctions, like those against South Africa in the eighty seconds, were super effective because they were almost universal. But, uh, otherwise, they often fail.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Goods sanctions are most effective when they are imposed by virtually the entire world. A notable example is the extensive sanctions levied against South Africa in the 1980s, which played a significant role in facilitating the downfall of the apartheid regime. Unless they are nearly universal, however, trade sanctions are often less effective than expected.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's like, unless everyone's on board, traders just reroute stuff. Iran's famous for, like, their oil-smuggling network. And Chinese goods still get into the US, just through Vietnam or Mexico.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's like, unless everyone's on board, traders just reroute stuff. Iran's famous for, like, their oil-smuggling network. And Chinese goods still get into the U S, just through Vietnam or Mexico.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: One reason for this is that unless there is near-universal global participation, traders can easily redirect sanctioned goods through third-party countries. Iran, for example, has managed to circumvent Western sanctions by constructing a sophisticated oil-smuggling network. Similarly, sanctioned Chinese goods are reportedly still entering the US market, as China-based firms reroute their exports through countries like Vietnam and Mexico.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But financial sanctions are a different beast, though. Because the dollar is so dominant, US-imposed financial sanctions, like during the Iraq War, proved to be way more effective. They've actually increased tenfold in the last 20 years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But financial sanctions are a different beast, though. Because the dollar is so dominant, U S-imposed financial sanctions, like during the Iraq War, proved to be way more effective. They've actually increased tenfold in the last twenty years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These secondary sanctions proved to be significantly more effective than traditional commodity trade sanctions, largely owing to the dollars dominant role in global finance. Consequently, US-imposed sanctions have increased tenfold over the past 20 years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, that brings us to Russia, right? After the Ukraine invasion, unprecedented trade and financial sanctions, even a $60-a-barrel price cap on oil. The goal was to cripple them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, that brings us to Russia, right? After the Ukraine invasion, unprecedented trade and financial sanctions, even a sixty dollars-a-barrel price cap on oil. The goal was to cripple them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Following Russian President Vladimir Putins full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, the US and its allies imposed unprecedented trade and financial sanctions on Russia, including a ban on technology and military exports. They also introduced a $60-per-barrel price cap on Russian oil, designed to cripple Russias economy while ensuring that Europe could avoid a politically destabilizing energy crisis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But, um, that hasn't exactly gone to plan, has it? By November 2023, Russian oil was, like, $84 a barrel. They've developed this whole shadow fleet and ghost trade.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But, um, that hasn't exactly gone to plan, has it? By November twenty twenty three, Russian oil was, like, eighty four dollars a barrel. They've developed this whole shadow fleet and ghost trade.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By November 2023, it had risen to $84.20 as Russian companies developed various methods of circumventing Western restrictions, such as inflated shipping costs and a shadow fleet consisting of more than 100 old tankers. Meanwhile, more than $1 billion in sanctioned goods have reportedly vanished amid the expansion of the Russian ghost trade.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I know! And countries like India, China, Armenia, the UAE, they've become these "laundromats" for Russian oil and other sanctioned goods. A Greek company even sold Russian oil to the US military!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know! And countries like India, China, Armenia, the U A E, they've become these laundromats for Russian oil and other sanctioned goods. A Greek company even sold Russian oil to the U S military!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, the Russia sanctions regime has given rise to a number of intermediaries, with countries like India, China, Armenia, Greece, Turkey, the United Arab Emirates, and Singapore effectively becoming laundromats for Russian oil and other sanctioned goods. One Greek company even sold Russian oil to the US military.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild. And it really makes you question the long-term effectiveness, you know? While sanctions might hurt Russia's GDP a bit, the evasion is just rampant.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild. And it really makes you question the long-term effectiveness, you know? While sanctions might hurt Russia's G D P a bit, the evasion is just rampant.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To be sure, Western sanctions have reduced Russias revenues and dented its GDP, albeit to a lesser extent than many had hoped. But the prevalence of sanctions evasion calls into question the effectiveness of the current regime and underscores the need for Western powers to consider the costs and risks to their own economies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And the flip side, B, is the cost to *us*. The more we use the global financial system as a weapon, the more countries might look for alternatives to the dollar.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the flip side, B, is the cost to us. The more we use the global financial system as a weapon, the more countries might look for alternatives to the dollar.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But the longer the global financial system is used as a tool of economic warfare, the more governments and businesses in third-party countries will look for alternatives to the dollar, euro, and the SWIFT international payment system.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. That could seriously erode the dollar's prominence, and the costs to the US and global economies could, um, far exceed any benefits from these sanctions. It's a really complex picture.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. That could seriously erode the dollar's prominence, and the costs to the U S and global economies could, um, far exceed any benefits from these sanctions. It's a really complex picture.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Should the Russia sanctions regime significantly erode the dollars prominence in international financial markets, the cost to the US and global economies could far exceed its benefits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. It just underscores the need to really weigh those costs and risks. Thanks for breaking that down, B!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. It just underscores the need to really weigh those costs and risks. Thanks for breaking that down, B!
